text: Interesting story on how we think we’re more candid than we are: <http://theatln.tc/1VMCKEc>

attachments.title: How Surveillance Stifles Dissent on the Internet
attachments.text: New research shows that social-media users who said they have “nothing to hide” from the government often avoid posting controversial opinions on Facebook.
attachments.fallback: The Atlantic: How Surveillance Stifles Dissent on the Internet

text: i'm wondering about the methodology of that study. just because i don't share a controversial opinion doesn't mean government surveillance had anything to do with the decision
perhaps people who think they have nothing to hide simply are less likely to be opinionated in the first place
not calling bullshit or anything, it's just not very well-explained

<@U0546QERR>: Some of the worst and most difficult reporting is on studies. Researchers and journalists don’t really speak the same language and the latter often draw sweeping conclusions based on a misunderstood abstract. That said, I think there’s a lot of truth to the idea that the awareness of being watched or seen changes our behavior. #panopticon. But I agree this is no slam dunk.
yep no denying the hawthorne effect. when i'm posting on facebook though, i'm much more concerned about how my family & friends perceive me than the government
the only variable in the situation seems to be that popup dialog telling them their actions are being monitored
you're probably right though, the journalists can put whatever spin they want on the study when they translate the results for their readers
